importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: Date when Pastor David Black reported being struck with pepper balls during a protest in Albany Park, prompting judicial scrutiny over use of force and lack of warnings.
Date of the hearing where Judge Sara Ellis pressed federal officials on enforcement practices during Operation Midway Blitz, highlighting ongoing legal and policy concerns.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: Period during which Operation Midway Blitz conducted over 1,000 arrests of migrants across Illinois, forming the context for federal enforcement and subsequent legal challenges.

keyTakeAways: Judge Sara Ellis expanded her temporary restraining order to require federal agents to turn on body-worn cameras when interacting with demonstrators, citing concerns about unannounced use of tear gas and pepper balls.
CBP agents in Chicago (over 200) are required to wear body cameras, but ICE Special Response Teams have not been issued cameras and would need congressional approval to receive them.
ICE agents are trained in crowd control, use of force, and handling journalists, with specific protocols for press engagement and non-interference.
A pastor, Rev. David Black, reported being struck multiple times with pepper balls during a protest without prior warning, raising concerns about compliance with protest safety standards.
Federal leadership in Chicago has been described as a 'revolving door' with frequent personnel changes, including Russell Hott leaving the Chicago field office to return to Washington, DC.
ICE leadership and the Office of Professional Responsibility review all use-of-force incidents to determine compliance with policy, but there are concerns about transparency and accountability.
The Trump administration has denied reports of tear gas use without warning, with officials claiming the judge relies on 'one-sided and selectively edited media reports.'

summaryOfNewsArticle: U.S. District Judge Sara Ellis is actively investigating the federal response to protests in Chicago during Operation Midway Blitz, a large-scale ICE enforcement operation that led to over 1,000 migrant arrests. In a hearing, she expanded her temporary restraining order to require body-worn cameras for agents interacting with demonstrators, citing concerns about unannounced use of tear gas and pepper balls. CBP agents are required to wear cameras, but ICE Special Response Teams have not received them due to lack of funding and approval processes. Testimony revealed that ICE agents are trained in crowd control and media handling, yet a pastor, Rev. David Black, reported being struck multiple times without warning while praying outside a detention facility. The federal leadership has been described as unstable, with frequent personnel turnover, including the departure of Russell Hott, who is now being deposed. The Trump administration denies reports of unapproved force use, claiming the judge relies on biased media. Judge Ellis will continue questioning senior officials to assess compliance with her order and transparency in enforcement practices.
title: Judge Presses Federal Officials on Response to Chicago Protests
